subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... I m not doing this just for one thing. In my experience moving a complex method to a place where it wants to be public both - makes the code more
messageBody:
>> The trick is to refactor it so that it moves to a different class
>> where it *should* be public. And in my experience, that's very likely
>> always possible, in a way that makes the design more flexible and
>> the behaviour more reusable.
>>
>> Does that sound reasonable?
>
> "Let us redefine progress, to mean that just because we /can/
> do a thing, it does not necessarily follow that we /must/ do
> that thing." So I suppose it would depend on several factors.
>
> 1. Are you doing this /just/ so that you can test the method
> by external invocation? If so then my answer is no. 2. Is the
> method already tested through the public API of the class? If
> yes then my answer is no. 3. Does the system (code plus
> tests) clearly communicate everything that needs to be
> communicated at this time? If it does then my answer is no.
> 4. Is the flexibility and reusability that you refer to
> needed now or is it speculative? If the latter then my answer
> is no. 5. Was my answer no to the previous questions and
> there are more stories needing to be implemented this iteration? Then
> heck no!

I'm not doing this "just" for one thing. In my experience moving a complex
method to a place where it wants to be public both

- makes the code more expressive,
- makes the code easier to test,
- makes the code more flexible, and thereby
- helps me to maintain a high velocity.

Also keep in mind that moving the method often is only a first step, an
enabler for further simplifying refactorings.

Cheers, Ilja
